normalised: **Environmental News: Rethinking Waste Management in India**

unnormalised: Experts at IIT-Madras are urging a paradigm shift in India's waste management strategies, moving beyond traditional landfill approaches. With Diwali and other festivals generating tonnes of extra waste, sustainable practices are more crucial than ever.
normalised: Experts at I I T-Madras are urging a paradigm shift in India's waste management strategies, moving beyond traditional landfill approaches. With Diwali and other festivals generating tons of extra waste, sustainable practices are more crucial than ever.

unnormalised: A recent study highlights that over 60% of municipal solid waste ends up in landfills, contributing to environmental pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. The focus needs to be on source segregation, encouraging households to separate biodegradable waste (like vegetable peels and leftover biryani) from recyclables.

unnormalised: Effective waste management requires community participation. Awareness campaigns are vital to educate citizens about composting techniques and the benefits of recycling. Several NGOs in Delhi are working with local communities to promote door-to-door collection and proper disposal methods.

unnormalised: Investing in waste-to-energy plants and composting facilities could significantly reduce landfill burden. The report also emphasizes the need for stricter enforcement of waste management regulations and promoting circular economy principles. A cleaner India for generations to come requires immediate and sustained action. The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan is a good start, but much more needs to be done.
